page.title: 01Sawston and Babraham
page.content: This is block comprises two villages- {Babraham,}whose name is derived from Beaduburgh, a Saxon chieftainess, and literally was 'Barbara's Ham', and Sawston. Babraham is a small village within 2387 acres of farmland lying 6 miles SE of Cambridge on the river Granta, bounded by an ancient Roman road to the north and Icknield Way to the east. There is one village street,'High Street', with development mainly on the SE side. Written records of{Sawston}go back to AD970; it lies close to the river Granta and is sheltered from the NE by the Gog Magog hills. The population has quadrupled in the last 25 years and now stands at 7200. Within the village nucleus may be found medieval houses and inns and two manorial dovecotes. Much of Sawston is protected by Cambridge Green Belt.
